;A few months ago, I experienced a thrilling scene and walked through the gate of hell. I was walking on the streets of Hefei when I suddenly heard a loud noise behind me. When I looked back, I was shocked out of my mind. A piece of concrete and ceramic tile mixture the size of a washbasin fell from a building more than ten stories high and hit me about two meters behind me. The debris from the impact splashed on my pants. I was so frightened that I turned pale. I really felt that life was so fragile and that I was so close to death.

;

;Later I talked about this distress in my circle of friends and social media, and I was thankful for my good luck. Unexpectedly, netizens have talked about nearly ten people who have encountered similar situations! It turns out that falling objects from heights are not an occasional phenomenon, but a frequent social problem.

;

;In the following months, four more incidents of falling objects from high altitudes occurred in my circle of relatives and friends. Two of them happened in the community where my sister lives (which was delivered in 2007): both times, weathered and peeling pieces fell from the top of the building. Once, the mortar hit the seat of the electric motorcycle, but no serious damage was caused; the other time was more serious. It was serious, the roof of the car was damaged, and the property management paid 3,000 yuan in compensation.

;

;The Supreme Court's 2020 "Trends and Characteristics of Cases of Falling Objects Injuring People from Height" report shows that civil cases of falling objects from heights are increasing year by year, and nearly 30% cause casualties. Xu Jianfeng, director of the Supreme People's Court Information Center, said: 18.16% of cases involved fatalities.

;

;Professional legal practitioners introduced more detailed and specific technical details of cases of falling objects from high altitude:

;

;Under the influence of the earth’s gravity, high-altitude objects have huge potential energy and fall close to the ground. At this time, it is converted into kinetic energy. At this time, the speed is fast and the momentum is large. When hitting the human body, the human body will receive a large impulse and force. A 30-gram egg dropped from the 4th floor can break a person's head; if dropped from the 18th floor, it can break a person's skull. Even lighter cigarette butts, fruit cores, cans... falling from high altitudes are likely to cause casualties once they hit the human body.

;

;More than 60% of criminal cases caused by falling objects occur in residential areas. They are closely related to the people, are related to personal safety and social stability, and cannot be ignored.

;

;According to "Qingdun Data": From 2014 to 2020, more than 1,450 high-altitude parabolic cases were concluded by courts across the country, showing an overall rapid growth trend. Among them, in 2020 alone, 451 cases were concluded. These are only the cases concluded by the courts. Many of the cases are minor and the cases where the parties have gone through mediation or reconciliation are not included in the calculation. According to incomplete statistics, there are actually more than 1,000 cases of high-altitude parabolic objects occurring in my country per year.

;

;There are four main reasons for high-altitude throwing cases: those who throw objects for convenience and casually account for the most, accounting for 55.1%; crimes of passion caused by quarrels and disputes account for 29.7%; malicious venting accounts for 13.2%; Laziness accounts for 2% of the cases.

;

;The above four types are classified as criminal cases of man-made thrown objects. In addition, falling objects from heights are also caused by the aging of buildings: the cement and ceramic tiles on the exterior walls of buildings have been damaged by wind, sun, and damage for many years. Rain... peel off and fall off after weathering. For example, the author was in danger and the vehicle in my sister's neighborhood was damaged by falling objects, which were all caused by the aging of the building exterior walls.

;

;Friends in the construction industry said that most of my country's high-rise buildings were built rapidly during the "explosive development of real estate" in the past 25 years or so, and it took a quarter of a century to go through four centuries of Western development. The development history of architecture. Many buildings are built quickly and in a hurry to meet the schedule. Of course, the quality of slow work and meticulous work cannot be achieved, and there are many potential hidden dangers. After more than 20 years of exposure to wind, sun, and rain, many buildings lacked maintenance, and problems gradually began to appear.

;

;Communicate with friends in the construction and property fields and learn about some ways to reduce the risk of falling objects caused by aging buildings. For example: not only should problems such as illegal construction and illegal renovation be dealt with, but also structures such as "parapets" on the top of old high-rise buildings should be demolished; exterior wall tiles can also be transformed into exterior wall paint, so that even if there are paint chips and wall dust falling off , it is not as lethal as the concrete and ceramic tile mixture falling.

;

;In the past, in traditional markets in southern cities such as Guangzhou, there were long corridors extending above the storefronts along the street and connecting them to one another. In the past, it was mainly used to shade the sun and rain, and to facilitate attracting customers and doing business. However, this kind of building structure has inadvertently become a buffer for falling objects from high altitude, reducing the casualty rate in accidents.

;

;The problem of falling objects from heights deserves attention and cannot be solved solely by legislation, judiciary, publicity and education. If you wait until after a casualty accident occurs before trying and making compensation, this kind of hindsight will not only fail to solve the problem, but will actually increase social instability. It’s the old saying: As long as your thinking doesn’t slip, there are always more solutions than difficulties. Combined with the current reconstruction of old cities, there are always ways to deal with the problem of falling objects from heights.

;Those who consider themselves "night owls" may need to pay attention. A new study in the United States found that the habit of going to bed late and getting up late may lead to a significantly increased risk of type 2 diabetes compared with going to bed early and getting up early.

;

;Researchers at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Massachusetts found that people with irregular sleep schedules have a higher risk of diabetes and cardiovascular disease, while people who go to bed later and get up later are more likely to develop diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Irregular sleep patterns. Relevant results have been published in the American monthly Annals of Internal Medicine.

;

;The researchers analyzed data collected from 63,676 female nurses between 2009 and 2017, including self-reported sleep type, diet quality, weight, health status, body mass index, sleep duration, smoking behavior, Alcohol use, physical activity, and family history of diabetes, and diabetes status was determined based on participant self-report and medical records.

;

;About 11% of the participants said they were "sleeping late and getting up late", about 35% said they had the habit of going to bed early and getting up early, and the remaining participants were labeled as "intermediate". The results found that before considering other lifestyle factors, compared with the "early to bed and early to rise" type, the "late to bed and late to rise" type may lead to a 72% increase in the risk of developing diabetes; after adding other lifestyle factors, the risk of developing diabetes still increased19 %.

;

;Research has found that people who have the habit of going to bed late and getting up late are more likely to drink heavily, have a low-quality diet, sleep less, smoke, and have an unhealthy weight and body mass index.

;

;Next, the researchers plan to study the impact of genetic factors on sleep timing patterns as well as cardiovascular disease and diabetes in a larger, more diverse population, and to assist doctors in better designing relevant strategies for their patients. prevention strategies.

;

;Ding Ju, 1920s, Ding Ju’s family collection;;

;

;"This is a situation that we use the current (very) fashionable and very popular expressions of "slash", "cross-border" and "cross-media" to describe it. A person who has absolutely no sense of incompatibility between his work and his career."

;

;As early as 6 years ago, Gu Zheng, a professor at the School of Journalism at Fudan University, began to plan an exhibition to present a person in his heart who has been forgotten by time. The life and works of the "giant of visual culture in the Republic of China".

;

;;

;

;Nanyang Brothers Tobacco Company Monthly Plates, Ding Xue depicts the person, Zhang Guangyu added the scene, circa 1925, 31.8cm×126.5cm, Zhang Weizang

;

;This person’s name is Ding Wei, whose courtesy name was Muqin, was born on September 16, 1891 in Fengjing Town, Jiashan County, Zhejiang Province during the Republic of China (;now Jinshan District, Shanghai ;), passed away in Shanghai in 1969.

;

;;

;

;"Higher and Higher" Ding Ju's comic, 1933, 7.5cm×5.5cm, published on the second page of "Social Daily" on March 20, 1934, Ding Jujia Zang

;

;Ding Wei is the father of the cartoonist Ding Cong. He is not only a prolific painter, but also an art educator and art activist. Cartoons, calendar paintings, newspaper cover illustrations, graphic advertising design; photography, guest roles in operas, radio broadcasts, writing theater reviews, organizing cultural salons... He participated in all kinds of visual expression and communication styles during the Republic of China, and he was also playing and playing. A versatile artist, his creations and life were the subject of intense pursuit by the media of that era, but for a long time afterwards, little was known about Ding Wei and his contributions.

;

;;

;

;"Saturday" No. 51, cover, Ding Wei, 1915, courtesy of Shanghai Library

;

;"My grandfather was also in the cultural circle during the Republic of China. He was quite a famous celebrity, but no one really knew him for the next sixty or seventy years. In terms of personal factors, he suffered from ear disease in the 1940s, which later developed into deafness in both ears, and he also suffered from ear disease in the 1950s. Glaucoma caused blindness in his right eye. Not only was he unable to draw, but he also had great difficulties in socializing, so he faded out of social activities. In the 1960s, he was labeled as a "reactionary academic authority", not to mention that in the 1970s, he set things right and restored his reputation, but the process was long. , and it did not immediately apply to him. In the 1980s, the "Creation Society" and the "Literary Research Association" were prominent in modern literature. My grandfather's circle of friends basically belonged to the "Mandarin Butterfly School" literati, and they would naturally be forgotten. Until a few days ago It was proposed in 2001 to explore Shanghai-style culture. Shanghai's cultural history before 1949 began to be viewed as a complete cultural ecology. In addition to the pioneering role of the 'New Culture Movement', academic research focused more on the entertainment and media related to ordinary people in the city. My grandfather was also 'unearthed' under such a background as all kinds of popular culture."

;

;;

;

;"Game Magazine" Issue 8, cover, Ding Wei, 1914, Courtesy of Shanghai Library

;

;From 1944 to 1945, Ding Ju wrote a column "Memoirs of Forty Years of the Art Circle" for "Oriental Daily", recording anecdotes about the maritime art scene in the late Qing Dynasty and the Republic of China, including vivid Vivid literary and artistic gossip, exciting and interesting stories experienced and heard personally, avant-garde and open urban culture, etc. In the past two years, Ding Xia, Ding Xue's grandson, has compiled these words that his grandfather scattered in newspapers and periodicals into "Memoirs of Forty Years in the Art Circle (1902-1945)". After reading this book, you will find that the sexually promiscuous painter Ding Wei, with humorous and exquisite words, inadvertently drew a map of the heroes of the Shanghai-style art circles during the Republic of China.

;

;;

;

;Daqianmen cigarette advertisement, published on the back cover of "British American Tobacco Company Monthly", Volume 5, Issue 6, 1925, Dingwei, 1925

;

;"Dingwei He was an important promoter of the emergence and development of Shanghai's visual culture during the Republic of China, a pioneer and practitioner of Shanghai's business culture in the international metropolis, and a leader of rich and colorful Shanghai urban culture." In the spring of 2023, "Mou" planned by Gu Zheng "Piano Career—Documentary Art Exhibition on the 130th Anniversary of Ding Wei's Birth" was unveiled at the Liu Haisu Art Museum in Shanghai. The exhibition salvaged a creative Ding Wei from the depths of history through 767 exhibits. In August, Gu Zheng edited and published "Mu Qin's Career: Ding Xu and Modern Art and Culture of the 20th Century", "I hope to use Ding Xu's 'pen' and 'lens' to show today's audience what happened in the first half of the 20th century." The rich and diverse cultural ecology and interests unfolding in Shanghai provide a glimpse into the origin and grand occasion of the 'Shanghai Style' new culture."

;

;;

;

;"Arhat", Ding Wei Photography, 1928, published in " "Shanghai Pictorial" Issue 321, February 9, 1928, Ding Ju's family collection

;

;;

;

;"Art Calligraphy Scrapbook", inside page, Ding Wei, 1920s and 1930s, 32.2cm ×28cm, Ding Ju's family collection

;

;"Old Painter of the Republic of China"

;

;In the old photo, Ding Ju sits upright, wearing a Chinese long coat and round-framed glasses, with a "fresh head" ", the wind spirit is loose and clear, and has a refined and scholarly spirit. Looking at the lower left corner again, he painted the character "D" into a small open umbrella, and connected the character "瀬" underneath which looks like an umbrella holder with "vertical by the heart". The playful and vivid signature reveals that this "old painter of the Republic of China" "The naughty nature at heart.

;

;;

;

;Photograph of Zhang Yuguang, Ding Ju and Liu Haisu, collected by Ding Ju’s family in the early 20th century

;

;Among Ding Ju’s colorful labels, he is the cartoonist The most well-known and praised identity. From the 1910s to the 1940s, Ding Wei published more than a thousand cartoons in newspapers and periodicals. His large-scale creations reflected his active exploration of comic forms and visual presentation in newspapers and periodicals.

;

;“Shanghai’s paper media was developed at that time, and he was responsible for a large number of cover paintings, illustrations and graphic advertisement designs that appeared in newspapers and magazines. The pictures he personally drew were fresh in appearance and unique in conception, which attracted everyone’s attention. The pages of newspapers and periodicals are bright, and readers are eager to see them." Gu Zheng emphasized, "In that era when it was possible to discuss the treacherous and ever-changing current affairs and public sentiments, cartoons were an important means for Ding Wei to express his opinions and participate in promoting social progress. Whether it is through continuous Whether it is the way of painting that reveals the critical point of current affairs or the single-frame cartoons that are sharp, they are all his specialties. Ding Wei, because of his cartoons and graphic images, contributed greatly to the development of paper media in the Republic of China."

;

;1909 to 1910 During the year, "Picture Daily", China's earliest daily pictorial, published a total of 7 "Mu Qin's manuscripts", including comic works such as "I am a Diplomat" and "Don't You See This Powerful World" by Ding Ju. At the age of 19, when he first tried his hand at crying with a comic pen, Ding Wei had not received professional training, but he was able to outline precise images with smooth simple pens. For example, in the comic "Members of the Autonomous Bureau's Moneyism", Ding used an exaggerated technique to draw a giant magnifying glass filled with coins in front of a member's belly, using the "clear vision of an The hypocritical appearance of devoting oneself to local autonomy only to seek power and personal gain satirizes "the election of autonomous bureau members inside and outside the city is full of strange phenomena."

;

;Ding Ju has been fond of painting here and there since he was a child, and his neighbors praise him as a "child prodigy" who can "paint gods like gods and ghosts like ghosts." His father died young, and as the eldest son, Ding Wei shouldered the heavy responsibility of supporting the family. When he was 13 years old, he left Fengjing Town and went to Shanghai alone to join his relatives. When he entered the old Beimen Changtai Pawn Shop as an apprentice, he still fell in love with art. Not long after he submitted and published cartoons for "Picture Daily", Ding Ju entered the Chinese and Western painting correspondence school founded by Zhou Xiang (1871-1933). For nearly a year, he concentrated on sketching, watercolor and oil painting.

;

;;

;

;"Landscape - Leifeng Pagoda", Ding Ju's photography, 1920s, Ding Ju's family collection

;

;"Mr. Zhou is good at traditional Chinese painting, gold and stone and calligraphy, and he is also very good at poetry. Well, Western painting became a monk halfway, and it seems not as pure and good as Chinese painting. He often makes caricatures for newspapers. His style is like Feng Zikai, and his brushwork and creativeness are even better than Feng." Ding Ju commented that Zhou Xiang was "extremely perverse in nature. , unwilling to be a trendy work," and his own signature also comes from the inheritance of this mentor, "His signature is "Zhou Xiang", written horizontally in parallel, which is the first of its kind for Western-style signatures. My signature on the painting , I was influenced by him, or it can be said that I completely imitated him. His signatures are very vivid and beautiful, while my signatures are clumsy and ugly."

;

;Zhou Xiang founded the Shanghai Oil Painting Academy, the China Academy of Art and many other Xu Beihong called him "the first person to establish an art school in Shanghai". Judging from the "Picture Notes" Ding Ju accumulated in the Chinese and Western Painting Correspondence School, Zhou Xiang once taught Ding Ju comic painting (cartoons). "The fun of comic paintings lies in sustenance, so its meaning should be shallow and its meaning should be deep." Zhou Xiang pointed out that to draw good comic paintings, you need to use exaggerated techniques to deal with the characters, so that "weird shapes make people laugh." Ding Ju's later comics practice always followed Zhou Xiang's teachings.

;

;In April 1911, Ding Ju, Zhang Yuguang, Qian Binghe, Ma Xingchi, Shen Bochen and others co-founded "Funny Pictorial". Although it only published one issue, it was one of the earliest comic publications in China. In August of this year, the supplement "Free Talk" of "Shenbao" was launched. According to Ding Ju's recollection: "My debut illustration was "Free Talk" which was first published in Shenbao when it was edited by Mr. Wang Dugen. At that time, there were not many cartoonists, only deceased friends. Brother Shen Bochen can be called the authority." He has written many articles in memory of his friend Shen Bochen, "I admit that he is an unprecedented success in our country through his caricatures, and he is the only one I have ever admired throughout my life. Not only he The thought has profound connotations, and the harmonious beauty of the structure and lines makes people intoxicated and admired." What impressed Ding Wei the most was an illustration of Shen Bochen's "involving a huge disaster", "The picture is of a house where pigs are being slaughtered, A German drove a group of pigs into this pig-slaughtering house. The pigs were part of the Allied Powers. Therefore, they greatly aroused the anger of the British and Americans... It was intolerable that such an unnatural act happened within the scope of his concession. ? This caused great disturbances and almost caused major international negotiations... After this big shock, "Shen Shen" did not publish any caricatures until before the war."

;

;;

;

;"Pan Xueyan ", Photographed by Ding Ju, 1928, published in "Shanghai Comics" Issue 29, 1928, Ding Ju's family collection

;

; From the 1910s to the early 1920s, Ding Ju was a long-term contributor to "Declaration·Free Talk" , drew a large number of cartoons, illustrations and masthead illustrations, participated in "free talks" many times, and published several game articles, short stories and drama talks; during the same period, he had close contacts with literati such as Wang Dugen and Zhou Shojuan. As the "visual director" of literary and artistic publications such as "Game Magazine" and "Saturday", Ding Wei has contributed a series of cover paintings and illustrations with great aesthetic interest. In the early years of the Republic of China, he and his colleagues in the art and literary circles jointly created an urban reading culture of leisure, entertainment, and fashion.

;

;In 1914, Chen Xiaodie wrote a poem for the "Two Parts of Spring" painted by Ding Kui, and once expressed emotion: "When reading Mu Qin's paintings, there are often poems, but I regret that my pen cannot express the meaning." At that time, he was painting covers for magazines, and Ding Wei's works were the most common. In 1916, when Zhang Guangyu, who was 9 years younger, met Ding Xu, "Old Ding was already quite successful and famous in Shanghai." This was Zhang Guangyu's feeling, and it was also Ding Xu's true status in society at that time. Ten years later, Ding Ju, Zhang Guangyu, Zhang Zhengyu, Ye Qianyu, Lu Shaofei and others established China's first comic society "Cartoon Club". As the first generation of cartoonists in China, these pioneers opened up a new situation for satirical and comic cartoons. The publication "Shanghai Comics" they founded nourished and promoted the younger generations, ushering in the golden age of cartoon art.

;

;About 1923, Ding Wei was spotted by a "headhunter" because of his superb painting skills, and joined the British American Tobacco Company to engage in advertising painting creation. As a senior figure in China's advertising industry, Ding Wei frankly admitted that "artists have no freedom" when they submit to business. "The most painful thing is that not only are manufacturers' advertising hosts very subjective, but most of them lack artistic accomplishment, and it is impossible to understand the author's ideas. He is often picky and picky and suggests unreasonable revision requirements. A work that was not bad at first was fragmented beyond recognition, making people laugh and cry."

;

;The calendar card that is still talked about today was once the commercial art of the Republic of China. Among them, Ding Ju is also one of the earliest painters of calendar painting. Wang Zengqi once said: Ding Ku's paintings, "The brushwork is somewhere between traditional Chinese painting and comics. There seems to be no such paintings now."

;

;;

;

;Inner page of "One Hundred Beautiful Pictures of the Style of the Republic of China", Ding Wei, 1918, published by China Federation of Literary and Art Circles Publishing House

;

;"Provost of the Academy of Fine Arts"

;

;"I was riding with Ding Jun in the car. Ding Jun looked around and saw young girls staring at each other. He stared blankly for a moment. I ridiculed him for being rude. Ding Jun said with a smile, "How can I be so lustful? I'm looking for painting materials." According to Wang Dugen's slightly ironic account, Ding Wei once "stared" on the bus without hesitation. Women, however, only want to accumulate "painting materials".

;

;In the early years of the Republic of China, "Hundred Beauty Pictures", which combined paintings of ladies and fashion, became popular. The young Ding's fame is closely related to the many volumes of beautiful pictures he drew. In August 1916, the Chinese Studies Bookstore launched "Ding Wei's Hundred Beautiful Pictures" (;Volume 1;). Due to the good response, it was published in February 1917 The second volume was published in the same month, and Ding Kui became famous in one fell swoop; in March of the same year, the Chinese Library released four volumes of "Ode to One Hundred Beautiful Pictures in Ancient and Modern Times" (; span>;), the ancient costume volume was written by Qiu Shounian, with a total of 100 pictures in the upper and lower volumes, and the fashion volume was drawn by Ding Wei, with a total of 50 pictures in the upper and lower volumes; in April 1918, the Shanghai Communications Library published "Ding Wei's Hundred Beauty Pictures" set". It can be said that Ding Wei's beautiful pictures and the "cover girl" he drew for "Saturday" were once all the rage and led the fashion of the times.

;

;"In Ding Xue's hundreds of beautiful pictures, there are ladies, small family biyu, fashionable girls, and graceful village girls. They wear shorts and trousers, braids and buns, fashionable and pleasant, and the furnishings of their rooms are also beautiful. It is full of popular atmosphere." Xu Tinghua wrote in "Ding Cong's Dad: Ding Chou": "In the era of the west wind spreading eastward, new ideas affected the lives of the younger generation, and they also affected Ding Chou. The women in the painting ride horses, skate, go outing, sketch, sketch, play the violin, dance ballroom, drive, and chat on the phone. They are all modern and reflect the advanced aesthetic consciousness of new women and painters at that time. The women are all beautiful and energetic. Exuberant, a new style of life."

;

;Gu Zheng pointed out that painting a hundred beautiful pictures at that time not only tested the artist's sensitivity to reality, but also gave the artist an opportunity to show off his talents. "Through this style, he (;Ding Wei;) used exquisite pen and ink to shape the reality and imagination of women in the early Republic of China, which was in the ascendant to help citizens’ visual consumption.”

;

;As early as the autumn of 1913, Ding Ju was invited to join the Shanghai Academy of Graphic Arts (;Later It was renamed Shanghai Fine Arts College;) and served as the dean. Due to her growing reputation for painting, in addition to teaching at Shanghai Fine Arts College, she was later hired as an art teacher by China Women's School, Tongji University and Yanmos Girls' School. At that time, female education was gradually accepted by the world. As a teacher in a girls' school, Ding Ju gained the convenience of "getting painting materials". After mastering photography technology, he also took the opportunity to focus on "Beauty" and take pictures of girls. He once said that photographing "girls from all schools is my duty." The photos taken by Ding Wei that remain today not only show the scenes of girls attending classes in coeducational art schools at that time, but also capture the style of girls in church girls’ schools at that time.

;

;;

;

;Ding Wei (second from left) and Zhang Guangyu (third from left), 1922, 22.5cm×40cm, courtesy of Zhang Guangyu Art Documentation Center

;

;About Women Ding Wei also wrote about the old stories of teaching in the school. "Song Ziwen's wife, Ms. Zhang Leyi, is also a student of Yan Mo's family... She always likes to dress up... She also wears heavy makeup and colorful clothes. Once, Shoujuan, Yunqian and I were watching a movie at the 'Odion' on North Sichuan Road. When the show was over, Yun Gu suddenly noticed a very beautiful girl in the crowd in front of us. She encouraged us: "Why don't you come forward and feast your eyes on it?" At this time, I saw clearly that it was our student Zhang Leyi and said: " Don't do anything nonsense. Those are our students. What's the point of being a teacher if they behave like this?" All the niches took a breath. Such jokes were common in the past, because at that time, I was in charge of several schools. , there are also many male and female students, so in the playground, they often don’t even dare to look at them. They don’t claim to be gentlemen, but they are actually seeking their own politics in their position. They have to do this because of their status.”;

;In terms of art education, Ding Wei also made outstanding contributions. He was the first provost of Shanghai Art College, the "source of emerging art". The principal of the school was Liu Haisu, an "art traitor" who dared to "fight" with the warlord Sun Chuanfang over mannequins. Ding Ju recalled this fellow junior He said, "He was extremely self-confident and refused to follow what others said. He focused on creation in his works throughout his life. However, in the early days, his calligraphy and painting were not unique and his boldness was indeed great. The world ignored the criticism and praise. He goes his own way, whether it is foreign or Chinese painting, a brute force can be observed in his paintings. His career achievements also depend on his unrelenting hard work. If you have a personality like mine, which is pragmatic and step-by-step, I’m afraid a hundred of them can’t compare to one of him.”

;

;Compared with many famous artists in Shanghai Academy of Fine Arts, Ding Wei’s influence has not been discovered before. From 1913 to 1918 when he was the dean and then teaching until 1928, he successively served as a teacher in the Western Painting Department, the Technical Normal Department, the Correspondence Department and the Pattern Department. He taught plaster models, copying, sketching, figures, watercolors, pencil drawings, and patterns. Production, advertising graphics and other courses... Despite the numerous achievements in teaching, Ding Wei is modest and self-deprecating: "I have never even stepped into kindergarten, let alone graduated from high school or university, but I am so shameless that I am a teacher in the south, not only in ordinary schools." , and even as a professor in universities and vocational schools, although the drawing class seems to be an exception, the criticism of 'daring' can never be escaped."

;

;The "daring" Ding Wei is in the United States During his tenure as a full-time teacher, he indeed made many pioneering achievements: in 1914, he, Zhang Yuguang, Xu Yongqing, Liu Haisu, etc. launched the Zhenqing Calligraphy and Painting Society and published the "Zhenqing Calligraphy and Painting Collection" as a model teaching material; in 1919, he, Jiang Xiaoyu, Liu Yanong, etc. , Zhang Chenbo, Yang Qingqing, Chen Xiaojiang and others established the art group "Tianma Club". By 1928, the "Tianma Club" held a total of 9 exhibitions, including Chinese paintings, foreign paintings, sculptures, photography and other styles, creating a trend of Chinese art exhibitions. Almost all the famous painters of that era had participated in the "Tianma Club" art exhibition.

;

;The reform of sketching instead of copying in Western painting teaching has gone through a long "struggle", especially on the issue of human body sketching. Ding Ju once argued in his "Essays on Paintings": "The painter is most qualified. The interesting thing is the sketching of the human body. Regardless of oil painting or sketching, I feel that there are infinite mysteries. Some people say that this is just because you are doing the painting with bad intentions. When you see the naked model, you probably have an incredible feeling. , so I feel that it is more interesting. I said God knows, this kind of interest is caused by the mystery of the various line structures on the human body, and the strange concave and convex contours. No curve in the world can be compared to the human body. Special. Only those who paint know this... To learn about climate changes, you must practice outdoor sketching; to learn the changes in outline and color, you must practice human body sketching."

;

;Learning from the Master. Ding Xue from Zhou Xiang received copying teaching in his early years. While teaching at the School of Fine Arts, he was inspired by Chen Baoyi to develop his knowledge and practice of life drawing. "In the beginning, those who studied Western painting in China were mostly copying, but it was not enough for training. Chen Baoyi advocated sketching as the basic practice... At that time, many teachers did not know how to teach, and I was just one of them. , I was extremely worried beforehand, fearing that I would make future scholars laugh, but he comforted me and taught me not to worry...taught me some important rules in sketching." According to Ding Ju's recollection, the studio he built by Chen Baoyi was returned to him. The practice of body photography has provided convenience. "Once Qi Foqing and I found a beauty and wanted to take a nude model. We didn't have a suitable location for a while, so we took a car to Jiangwan and practiced it at Ji's Studio. The result was that the light was soft and beautiful for any ordinary photography. It’s beyond the reach of the museum.”

;

;Although Ding Wei was not the central figure in the nude model controversy at the American College, until his later years, he firmly believed that hiring nude models for sketching was a pioneering work of the College of Art. In addition, Ding Wei admitted that he had been obsessed with collecting "nudity photos of men and women from all over the world, both male and female, or singles." When the collection was at its largest, "there were more than a thousand kinds, and most of them were secret scenes taken by Westerners... There were not many domestically produced ones, and the good ones were There are very few of them, and a single person can still watch them for a while. There are more than ten kinds of Japanese exaggerated pictures, and there are nearly a dozen of them made by famous Western hands. The lines are beautiful and the composition is strange."

;

;;

;

;"Lily";)

;

;In August 1925, Ding Wei and his family moved to No. 31 Tianxiang Lane, Baylor Road (;Today’s Lane 847, Huangpi South Road;), according to Ding Cong’s recollection: Ye Qianyu lived on the second floor of the alley across the street, Lu Zhixiang lived downstairs, Tewei lived in the back, and Zhang Guangyu lived No. 19. The Ding family is relatively spacious, with the living room on the first floor, Ding Ju and his wife living on the second floor, and the eldest son Ding Cong living on the third floor. For a time, this place became a base camp for talented people: Zhang Guangyu, Ye Qianyu, Lu Shaofei, Wang Renmei, Li Lili, Zhou Xuan, Jin Yan, Nie Er... Every weekend and holiday, talented people from all walks of life come in and out, talk and gossip. , and even "eat and drink".

;

;Huang Miaozi, who later became a frequent visitor, once recorded the first time he walked into Ding's house in 1932: "It was about a Saturday night, and a lot of movie and drama stars of the time were spread out in the living room and downstairs. In the room of uncle Ding's family on the second floor, there were three, three, five and five, everyone was enjoying themselves. Some of them called Ding Xue and Mrs. Ding to be their "fake father" and "fake mother". Because they were unexpected to see so many people at once. Celebrity, I was a little blushing and my heart was beating. I met Uncle Ding’s uncle in a hurry, so I hurriedly hid in Ding Cong’s cabin on the third floor.”

;

;;

;

;Ding Cong, who was still a middle school student at the time, often sat among these celebrities and listened to their chatter and laughter. Nie Er came to Ding's house. The young Ding Cong once pestered Nie Er into his upstairs "pavilion" and told him horror stories. "Once Nie Er was drunk, he walked to the patio and climbed along the wall. Go to the attic and sleep." The big stars of the Mingyue Song and Dance Club would always come to Ding's house in groups to play when they had free time. According to Ding Ju's memory, "(Xue) Lingxian was the most jumping among them, and she took the initiative in most of the tricks. At that time, her child Yiyi (;Ding Cong;) was about the same age as them, so Lingxian often ate Yiyi tofu and said, "As a child, Bai Zi (;Bai Hong;) is assigned to Xiao Ding, and I will be the matchmaker. (Wang) Renmei, (Li) Lili, and Hu Jiamen To reconcile the situation, Yiyi was very angry. When he saw them coming, he often avoided the table. Sometimes the pavilion where he lived alone was occupied by them, so he had to not go in."

;

;Wang Renmei, Li Lili, Bai Hong, etc. After becoming famous, they were followed by Zhou Xuan, who was still in the stage of career development. When Zhou Xuan was a trainee at Mingyue Club when she was twelve or thirteen years old, Ding Xuan had known her and cared for her. Zhou Xuan and "Mr. Old Ding" had a very close relationship, and they exchanged letters and gave photos frequently. However, in the later narratives about Zhou Xuan, Ding Xia rarely spoke up. Ding Xia said: "I also had such doubts. I once asked about my grandmother and Father. My grandmother completely regarded Zhou Xuan as a child and felt that she should not leave the family; my father said that my grandfather also favored Yan Hua (;Zhou Xuan in this matter Ex-husband;). At that time, public opinion was almost on Zhou Xuan's side, and she was even regarded as the 'runaway Nora'. My grandfather had always stayed away from right and wrong. Since public opinion was swayed to one side, he was unwilling to join in the fun and avoided those Tabloid reporter. After Yan Hua remarried, he stopped mentioning the old stories. When he was young, his grandfather was also considered a new-school literati, advocating that women should enter society and liberate themselves. However, in the 1930s and 1940s, he felt that he seemed to be a little behind the times. , he believes that women should pursue career development, but also put family first."

;

;In the newly published "Memoirs of Forty Years in the Art Circle" (;Collection Edition;)", Ding Xia added 12 letters between Ding Wei and Zhou Xuan. "Most of Zhou Xuan's letters to my grandfather were not dated. The two dated letters were written when she returned to Shanghai for medical treatment in 1957. In the letter, Zhou Xuan also stated that she would visit her grandfather after she recovered. My grandfather was naturally very happy and told several friends about the incident. However, he did not expect that just over two months after the last letter was written, Zhou Xuan died suddenly, which is really sad."

;

;Ding Among the photos collected by his family, there are many signed photos of celebrities, as well as photos of people from all walks of life taken by him. The gentle-tempered Ding Wei is well-known in the industry as a "nice gentleman". When interacting with friends, he often takes photos of the men and women around him because he carries a camera with him and has a great sense of service. Ding Ju, who is both a photographer and a fan of Peking Opera, has been close to a number of famous actresses and has left many photos of great documentary value.

;

;;

;

;" (Xun) Huisheng didn’t recognize me when he was born (;ding;). Sha Youtian taught him how to read square characters every day and also copied them. Copybook, considered his talent and intelligence, actually advanced very quickly, and later he even learned to paint." Ding Wei took a photo of this "illiterate famous lady" leaning on a rockery with his head bent and reading diligently, " One of the greatest advantages of Huisheng is that he is willing to receive advice from others. After every time he comes off the stage, he always asks everyone present whether there are any shortcomings on stage today or what needs to be improved. We always tell him truthfully and he will correct it next time. , he was one of the four famous Dandans, and it was not a coincidence at first."

;

;Ding Wei became a photography enthusiast and was influenced by his friend Lang Jingshan. When Lang Jingshan was working part-time in the advertising department of "Shenbao", Ding Ju noticed his high-end camera. "The mirror case was not brand new, but it was of a good brand, and it was a four-inch large reflector." However, "it was extremely heavy." ", Ding Wei teased Lang Jingshan, "No matter where he goes, he always carries this reflector like a chamber pot box with him, never leaving it for a moment. With his warm tone, it really makes people laugh. We got it for him. He was nicknamed "living in a chamber pot box.""

;

;Ding Wei, who is "an excellent photographer throughout his life," sometimes stood in front of the camera to "pose", and he was quite playful. In 1924, "Half Moon" published a photo of Zhou Shojuan and Ding Ju. Both appeared in women's clothing. Above it was a portrait of Zhou Shojuan in women's clothing when he was 14 years old, titled "Shoujuan Makeup", with a description next to it: "The so-called Prince Wenyan. Qianying (;Photographed fifteen years ago;)". Ding Wei once took over the chore of drawing illustrations for novels because of this "lovely friend", "I remember once, I drew the illustrations of "Ten Zhangs of Beijing Dust" and "The Record of Leftover Pink and Residual Fat" for Shoujuan's "Half Moon". Zhang is a bather in a bathhouse. They are all naked. There must be no mistakes in the drawings of each person's body... One picture shows a woman sitting on a low stool and sitting on a copper bed, cutting the nails of a young man... The composition It was difficult to arrange. I said to Shojuan, you have made me suffer. It is more difficult to draw these two illustrations than to draw ten colorful covers... Isn’t it unfair?"

;

;Ding Ju and Zhou Shojuan’s friendship It is true that the two had known each other for more than 50 years from the time of "Shen Shen·Free Talk" to when Zhou was 70 years old. In 1964, when Ding Wei was dying, it coincided with the 70th birthdays of Zhou Shoujuan, Zheng Yimei and Tao Lengyue. A group of old friends celebrated their birthdays at the time-honored Xinya Restaurant in Shanghai and took a group photo after dinner.

;

;"This is a serious and even a bit dull photo, which may be related to people's aging mood and current situation. Among the 22 people taking a photo together, most of them were very healthy people in Shanghai at that time. There are many intellectuals, and Ping Yanya, Cheng Xiaoqing, Lu Danan and Yan Duhe are all over seventy years old." Gu Zheng believed that this group photo was of "extraordinary significance" and made people think deeply about "the heavy fate of individuals in the great era" - four years later, in 1968, Zhou Shoujuan committed suicide by throwing himself into a well in Suzhou. Another year later, Ding Wei died of illness.

;

;;

;

;The autumn scenery of Jiyama Temple along Matsuo Basho's "Oku no Hosho" tour. ;(Photo provided by the author);

;

;Continue walking north. Get on the train from Nishinasuno Station, go to Nasushiobara Station, transfer to the Shinkansen to Koriyama, transfer to the main line and get off at Inaashiro Station. In a very small station, a huge public service announcement is very conspicuous on the glass of the station door. On it is a big picture of a sweet girl, and below it is written, "Check everything one by one to be careful of candles." In Japanese, the small fire candle is called "火の心", which is interesting. Waiting for the bus at the station entrance, get off at the Katada stop and arrive at the shore of Inaashiro Lake.

;

;Lake Inaashiro is the fourth largest lake in Japan. It is located in the center of Fukushima Prefecture and has transparent and clear water. The beauty of the four seasons of Bandai Mountain is reflected in it, like a sky mirror, so it is also called Tianjing Lake. From Jiantian Station on the roadside (there is just a road sign on the side of the road) to the lake, there is a straight small dirt road. On both sides of the road are harvested yellow-brown winter fields, and at the end of the road is a row of undulating crimson fields. The red tree, above the tree, was a vast sky covered with gray and white clouds. Although there was no actual sound, a loud rumbling sound suddenly rose in my heart. How could he just walk over like this? He must be running away! So he ran over like crazy.

;

;The business card of Lake Inaashiro is Hideyo Noguchi. Hideyo Noguchi, the man printed on the 1,000 yen note, is a world-famous bacteriologist who has made outstanding research achievements in serology, polio, rabies, syphilis, etc., which have benefited all mankind. In 1876, Hideyo Noguchi was born into a poor peasant family on the shores of Lake Inaashiro at the foot of Mount Bandai. He was a poor student who worked extremely hard. After studying at the Medical College in Tokyo, he went to the University of Pennsylvania in the United States for further study and research, and made significant achievements. In 1928, Noguchi Hideyo died of the yellow fever epidemic while researching yellow fever in Ghana, Africa. At that time, the United States took his body back to New York for burial. In Lake Inaashiro, his hometown built the Noguchi Hideyo Museum for him.

;

;We did not visit the Noguchi Hideyo Museum, but as of this writing, we cannot avoid the local business card. We didn't have much time at the time, and we had to return to the station to continue our journey north, so we strolled around the deserted lake.

;

;We stayed at a hot spring hotel in Tendo City, Yamagata Prefecture at night. There is a big black cat lying on the cabinet at the front desk of the hotel. The clerk said that it is the hotel's signature and the owner. Tendo is the home and production base of shogi. The status of shogi is equivalent to that of Chinese chess, but it is not clear how to play it. I have watched the Japanese movie "Holy Youth", which is a biopic about the seriously ill genius shogi player Murayama Sei. There are many scenes of chess and competitions in the film, which are quite arduous. At Tendo's hotel, I got a souvenir from the store, a small red shogi piece, which can be used as a key chain. When I got it and looked at it carefully, I suddenly thought: Does Chinese chess have a production base? In which city?

;

;Return to the trip. We entered Yamagata Prefecture to visit Tateishiji Temple (mountain temple), which is an important relic of the Oku no Hosōdo.

;

;In the morning, take the bus from Tendo Station to Yamagata Station, store your suitcases here, then continue to get on the bus, get off at Sandera Station, and start climbing the mountain. Lishi Temple, also known as Mountain Temple, was opened as the Taoist temple of Tiantai Sect in 860 by Master Cijue, an eminent monk of Tiantai Sect. The mountain here is steep and there are many strange rocks. After climbing all the way up, there are 870 stone steps from the mountain gate to the inner courtyard. This shrine is long and arduous and quite a tiring journey.

;

;Basho wrote in "Oku no Hosōdo" "Thirty Standing Stone Temple", "... When we got there, it was still dark, so we first settled down in the monk's room at the bottom of the mountain, and then went up the mountain. Went to pay homage to the monk hall. Along the way, we saw layers of dangerous rocks and boulders, lush old pines and cypresses, and the old earth and rocks were covered with moss, making it slippery and difficult to walk on. Many temples built on the top of the rocks were all The door was closed, and there was silence. Sometimes we crept on the edge of the cliff, sometimes we crawled on the giant rocks, visited the Buddhist temple, and looked at the surrounding scenery. As the saying goes, the beautiful scenery is lonely, quiet and peaceful, and I feel that my heart has become clear and transparent. "It's over."

;

;On the way to the entrance, Basho's famous sentence written here is engraved on the cliff, "The sound of the cicadas in the rock of leisure" (Want to know how quiet it is? The cicadas chirp deep into the rock). Out of breath, I reached a small flat land in the mountains. On top of stacks of rocks, there was a bronze seated statue of Master Basho and his disciple Zeng Liang resting in the mountains. Basho was wearing a turban and straw sandals, sitting on a tree root, tilting his head slightly and looking into the distance. There was a small cloth bag hanging on his chest, presumably containing paper and pens. Zeng Liang is sitting not far away, wearing a bald monk's robes, holding a wooden stick in his right hand and a bamboo hat in his left hand. In the chapter "Six Days of Light" in "Oku no Homichi", Basho specifically writes about Zeng Liang's change of clothes. When they were in Shenchuan, Zeng Liang and Basho lived next to each other, chopping firewood, boiling water, and doing daily housework for the teacher. When the two decided to travel to Austria together, before leaving, Zeng Liang shaved his head and put on black monk robes. When the two of them walked to the Black-Faced Mountain, Zeng Liang recited a sentence, "The black-haired people shaved off early, and unexpectedly encountered the Black-Faded Mountain. It's time to change clothes in spring and summer." Bajiao commented, "The word 'change' in it , is not just a simple phrase, but also contains his determination to change his identity and insist on traveling far away. It is sonorous, powerful and meaningful."

;

;;

;

;Matsuo Basho and Kawai Soryo on the way to the mountain temple bronze seated statue. ;(Photo courtesy of the author);

;

;The three of us each found a rock and sat with Basho Zengliang to rest for a while. The mountain breeze is strong and cool. If you stop for a while, the sweat will stop all over your body. There is a branch of miscellaneous trees behind the banana, and the scattered red leaves are shining like gems in the sun. In the distance is the green mountain scenery, and the green and transparent leaves in the backlight are like new green in early spring. This place and this scene should be the same as what Basho and Zeng Liang saw 330 years ago. Think carefully about the integration of time and space, and you will suddenly feel lucky for three lifetimes.

;

;Then, keep walking. Basho's footsteps are ahead.

;

;In "Oku no Hosōdo", Mount Haguro in Yamagata Prefecture is a highlight and must be visited.

;

;In the late autumn of 2019, which coincided with the first year of Reiwa, Japan’s new Emperor Naruhito ascended the throne. Haguro Mountain, where an important shrine is located, started from the Suishin Gate. There were many congratulatory posters on the approach to the shrine. . These congratulatory posters are not available in the street market. Along the way from Tokyo, from the market point of view, there was very little content related to the new emperor's enthronement. This shows that the changes in the Japanese royal family have little immersion and impact on people's daily life, let alone frequent changes. of the Japanese cabinet.

;

;Haguro Mountain is one of the three mountains of Dewa. The three mountains, Mount Haguro, Mount Yudono, and Mount Tsuki, are special sacred places in Japanese mountain belief. Among the three mountains, only Mount Haguro, which is 414 meters above sea level, can be climbed all year round. Mount Getsuki and Mount Yudono are 1,984 meters and 1,504 meters above sea level respectively. Both have closed seasons. The former is from early autumn to early summer, and the latter is in autumn. In spring, ordinary people cannot go. Mount Yudono is considered to be the final place of spiritual practice in the Dewa Sanzan. Its shrine cannot be called by its name, and photography is prohibited, making it very mysterious.

;

;;

;

;The mountain trail in Mount Haguro. ;(Photo provided by the author);

;

;Basho and his disciple Zeng Liang arrived at the Dewa Three Mountains in mid-summer in July, and visited all three mountains. . The two masters and apprentices climbed to the Moon Mountain. After reaching a certain altitude, they entered the snow. They were in a trance. "... They entered the cloud pass where the sun and moon travel. Their breath stopped and their bodies froze. Finally, when they reached the top of the mountain, the sun The moon is out." Along the way to Yueshan Mountain, Basho wrote a diary of his journey, but did not write a haiku. After that, he climbed to Tangdian Mountain, "...and sat on a stone to take a nap. I saw a cherry tree, about three feet high, with half-open buds and hidden flowers. In the snow, spring is not forgotten; the late cherry blossoms are as special as the fragrance of plum blossoms in summer." The most beautiful scenery of Yudian Mountain should be at the shrine on the top of the mountain. Basho said, "The details of the mountain are forbidden to be disclosed to outsiders, so Stop writing and not record." During the trip to Tangdian Mountain, Basho still did not write any haiku. Only at Mount Haguro, Basho lamented the beauty of the climb and recited, "It's rare to find something special. The mountain breeze carries the fragrance of snow and the southern valley is scented."

;

;We climbed Mount Haguro. The route is to climb from Suishenmen at the foot of the mountain to the top of the mountain, and then take a car down the mountain.

;

;There are various shrines along the mountain road. There is Sanzan Shrine on the top of the mountain. When believers worship here, it is equivalent to worshiping all three mountains. I looked at the map and saw that there were dozens of shrines scattered throughout Mount Haguro. Among them is Hayamazhi Shrine, which we passed by while climbing. In my opinion, this shrine is quite appropriate for Mount Haguro, where trees and leaves are the focus of attention. "It's awe-inspiring, the green leaves are intertwined, and the sun shines brightly." Basho wrote this haiku about Nikko in "Oku no Homichi". It is particularly suitable to put it on the scenery we saw along the way to Mount Haguro. Climbing the long and steep mountain road, dripping with sweat and out of breath, I occasionally stopped to look up and saw the bright autumn sunshine blowing in the wind between the leaves. Although I did not feel the "snow fragrance" that Basho mentioned, it was indeed fascinating. , tiredness is completely out of the question.

;

;Early autumn, mid-autumn and late autumn are quite vague concepts. In terms of time, this trip to Northeast Japan is already in the mid-autumn season, but what I saw along the way was clearly the scenery of early autumn. We entered Tohoku from Tokyo. During our short stay in Tokyo, there was still heat in the air. In Tohoku, where the latitude is high, the red leaves and yellow leaves are already a little bit scattered, while in areas outside Tohoku, such as Tokyo and Kyoto, the red leaves are still green.

;

;But this greenness is very subtle, it is the greenness that is about to leave, without any lingering flavor. In other words, the departure heel has already stood on tiptoe.

;

;The color of leaves has countless levels in a frame. The rotten leaf color is a very rich color system among the traditional Japanese colors. During the Heian period, there was a saying of the "forty-eight rotten leaf colors". The color of fallen leaves refers to the color of fallen leaves. I understand that the state of fallen leaves should be when the leaves have just fallen off the branches, not after they have fallen to the ground. Among the colors of rotten leaves, the color name "green rotten leaves" refers specifically to the green color that still retains the breath of summer. A very Zen statement.

;

;On the long mountain trail of Mount Haguro, there are fallen leaves the color of decayed green leaves everywhere. In the sunshine, those leaves that are about to fall or change color are like the new green in early spring, tender and bright. Along the way, there are traces of Basho, monuments, statues, and the "Basho Tomb", which is one of the many in Japan... I took out the "Oku no Homichi" I brought with me and took a photo with Basho to thank him for his kind blessing.

;

;The new green of early spring has a unique color term called moeki color, which has been used since the Heian period. The moe wood color is a fresh and bright green with a breath as thin as cicada wings. It is said that this color is often used in the armor of young samurai. This scene is described in "The Tale of the Heike", where a teenage samurai appears lightly wearing moegi-colored armor. It's hard to imagine how the texture of the armor could be harmonized with a color as delicate as bright green.

;

;There seems to be no difference between the green rotten wood color in early autumn and the cute wood color in early spring from the color matching post, at least I can't see any difference. The difference lies in the breath, in the relationship between these delicate greens and the wind, rain, and sky. The autumn sky is high and distant, and the depth of field is the deepest and most indifferent among the four seasons. It is silent and reticent.

;

;The color of green and decaying leaves has been with us since the beginning of this trip.

;

;In the book written by Nagasawa Yoko, a traditional Japanese color expert, she regards hagi cakes as the representative food of green leaf color. Hagi, also known as Lespedeza, is one of the seven grasses of autumn. Hagi mochi is a Japanese autumn seasonal food, which is a glutinous rice dumpling filled with bean paste that is common in Japan. If you want to emphasize the occasion, you will add a flowering lespedeza pattern. The red flowers and green leaves are all light and hazy. The soft colors and soft taste are combined into one.

;

;There is a song in "Man'yoshu" that says: "There has been a time like this; Junshang asked, have the Lespedeza flowers bloomed?"

;

;This trip we set off from Fukagawa, Tokyo. At that time, while looking into the courtyard of Bashoan's former site, I saw the flowering Lespedeza for the first time. The seated bronze statue of Basho faces the Sumida River. The autumn clouds are low to the horizon, the branches of Lespedeza are trembling in the wind, and the red flowers are swaying. Lespedeza is a simple shrub plant, and its branch and flower shapes are not stunning at all, but its light and contented little playfulness makes people very happy.

;

;Since there are hagi mochi in autumn, there are also corresponding seasonal foods in spring, which are rice cakes and oriole mochi.

;

;One March, when I was on a spring trip to Japan, I was in a restaurant. The shopkeeper served me a dessert, a diamond-shaped rice cake divided into three layers, one pink and one pink. It's white and the first layer is green. I always like this kind of simple snack, not too sweet, and I ate it happily. Later, when I read the book, I realized, oh, what I eat is water chestnut pancake. This water chestnut cake really has a very important meaning. The orthodox lozenge cake has three colors, peach represents peach blossoms, white represents lingering snow, and green represents spring buds. It is a typical spring snack and an important food for the Peach Blossom Festival in March. March 3rd is Hina Festival, also called Peach Blossom Festival or Girl's Day, which is derived from China's Shangsi Festival. During this festival, families with daughters will set up a doll stand in their home, with three, five, seven or nine layers, with figures in ancient costumes placed on each layer from bottom to top in descending order. Doll. The special foods on this day are clam chowder, chirashi sushi, dried mochi and water chestnut cakes.

;

;The so-called warbler cake is a glutinous rice ball wrapped with fillings and sprinkled with bean flour called warbler powder made from green beans. The traditional color represented by Oriole mochi is Oriole, which is the color of the feathers of an oriole. The tree warbler, also called the primula, has a thrilling call in early spring. There is a haiku in the corner of Basho's disciple's room, which says, "The oriole hangs upside down on the branch and makes its first cry." The color of the oriole I understand is matte yellow-green. This color name was born in the Edo period. Common people in the Edo period were prohibited from wearing bright and bright clothes, so matte orioles were very popular because of their subtle charm.

;

;I don’t know why, but I think it’s more appropriate for glutinous rice dumplings to be green. In small supermarkets in Japan, there are various kinds of glutinous rice dumplings called "Daifuku". The one I often buy is called "Cao Daifuku". The light green glutinous rice dumplings are wrapped in light green bean flour and filled with bean paste. "Sodaifuku" is very cheap, about 100 yen each, but if it is served at a formal banquet in the spring, it will be worth a lot of money, and its name will also change, becoming "Obama mochi". Maybe some people will laugh at me for thinking that the "Cao Dafu" in the supermarket is the same thing as Orioles cake. Maybe there are some differences between the two, but for me, who has dull taste buds, they are the same thing. I ate the last dessert at a spring Michelin-level kaiseki meal, a small green glutinous rice pancake. It was delicious. I thought happily, oh, it’s Sodaifuku. Then I looked at the menu at hand and it said: "Warbler Cake".

;

;From autumn to spring, spring and autumn flow. In spring and autumn, people are accustomed to skipping summer and winter, but these two seasons, which have no direct intersection, are used as synonyms for the years.

;

;In Basho's "Oku no Hosho", the first haiku is in "Departure", "Spring is about to pass, and it is useless to teach birds to sing gracefully and fish to have tears in their eyes." The last haiku is in "Departure". In "Ogaki", "Meat in a clam shell, seeing two things separated, autumn is about to go." It starts with "spring goes" and ends with "autumn goes", and the first sentence of the prologue part of "Oku no Hosomido" Yes, "The sun and moon are passers-by for hundreds of generations, and the years are also travelers." It is nothing more than two words, years.

;

;You will get tired of singing any song after a long time, but for the songs of the four seasons, generations of passers-by, travelers coming and going for thousands of years, no matter how you sing, there is never enough. Although all the songs will disappear, Basho said, "Precious people see lightning flying across the sky, but they don't realize that their lives are in vain." This very powerful haiku is a sentence of summer. I have always believed that summer is the most powerful season. In other seasons, my mood is flickering up and down, and I am not at ease, which is hard to say.

; Sun, 17 Sep 2023 21:25:04 +0800 出走半生，归来仍是《小时代》http://www.infzm.com/contents/256532
;;2023-09-17 20:00:00;
;

;;"Yunzhiyu" is undoubtedly A good start to the September season. ;

;

;;Yu Shu; The main CP led by Xin and Zhang Linghe continued the popularity of "Eternal Life Flower" in "Canglan Jue", and the supporting cast included Cheng Lei, Lu Yuxiao, Young actors such as Tian Jiarui also successfully "served on the table."

;

;But, what is the quality?

;

;After ten episodes, I just want to say: "Guo Jingming has been away for half his life, and he is still "Little Times" when he comes back."

;

;;

;

;;Although, after the series started airing, the chief director and The screenwriter's signature was changed to "Gu Xiaosheng", but familiar viewers know that Gu Xiaosheng is the pseudonym of Guo Jingming (Guo Xiaosi). The actual controller of Zuishi Culture, the co-producer of the series, is also Guo Jingming. ;

;

;;

;

;;In May this year, in the 2023-2024 major drama list released by iQiyi, the director’s signature Still Guo Jingming. ;

;

;;The story of "Cloud Feather" takes place in an imaginary ancient background. ;

;

;;The Gong family is a well-known and upright family in the world. They live in seclusion in deep mountains and valleys, living a nearly isolated life. ;

;

;;Broken down, there are four families with their own specialties: Shang, Jiao, Zheng, and Yu. ;

;

;;The wise and brave Gong Huanyu;;(played by Ji Lingchen);;and the frail Gong Ziyu;;(played by Zhang Linghe);;Is the son of the current leader of Gongmen. ;

;

;;

;

;;Gong Shangjiao of Jiao Palace;; (played by Cheng Lei);; is ruthless and has extraordinary abilities. Gong Yuanzheng (played by Tian Jiarui) of Zhenggong is good at making drugs and is a senior brother-controller who follows Gong Shangjiao all day long. ;

;

;;

;

;;

;

;;In addition to these four young masters, the Gong family also has a hilarious and nymphomaniac eldest lady Gong Zishang;; (played by Jin Jing);;. ;

;

;;

;

;;There is also a killer organization in the world called Wu Feng. It has been trying to dismantle the palace for many years and has sent out many undercover agents. ;

;

;;At the time when the palace is choosing a wife, the Wufeng female assassin Yun Weishan;; (played by Yu Shuxin);; and Shangguan Qian ;; (played by Lu Yuxiao) ;; sneaks into the Gong family with different tasks. ;

;

;;

;

;;This was a troubled year. The old leader and first heir Gong Huanyu died mysteriously. Gong Ziyu succeeded him at the critical moment and got the support of his sister Gong Zishang. However, the more powerful Gong Shangjiao is eyeing the leader, and Gong Yuanzheng has repeatedly provoked and secretly caused trouble for him. ;

;

;;With their beauty and strength, Yun Weishan and Shangguan Qian stood out from the many brides and lurked next to Gong Ziyu and Gong Shangjiao respectively. Where should their fate go? ;

;

;;

;

;;Although there are many characters and complicated subplots;, love is undoubtedly the main thread of this drama. In the final analysis, it is the story of a female undercover agent and a male target falling in love. ; With a sincere heart, he is entangled, confused, and finally makes a choice between mission and emotion. ;

;

;;

;

;;

;

;;On the other side, Gong Shangjiao and Shangguan Qian will stage a fox-rabbit love story. The two high-end game players gradually developed feelings that they did not expect during their testing, mediation, and pulling. For two people whose reason is greater than their emotions, they may have to compete for "who falls first" until the last minute. ;

;

;;

;

;;

;

;;;From this perspective, what Guo Jingming wanted to film ;; may be a variation of "Lust, Caution": men and women trapped in identities. They are on guard against each other, but it is difficult to resist physical attraction and the desire to be loved. Love is hard to hold on to, love is hard to find, those who are sober will pull away, and those who are infatuated will leave their tears empty.

;

;This requires a detailed description of emotions. It must be written that every decision made by a man in reason is mixed with overwhelming pain and lasting love, and it must be written that a woman's heart is shattered after all the tricks have been exhausted. I suddenly realized that he was the only one who cared about me. I wanted to write about the weakness of human nature, the burning body of love, and the dark thoughts growing secretly in the coffin-like mansion...

;

;But "Yun Zhi" "Yu" is not the ancient puppet version of "Lust, Caution", but "Tiny Times 5".

;

;Like August’s high school days in Chang’an, Shuang Xuetao’s frozen Northeast, and Han Han’s small towns and racing cars, many writers’ creations repeatedly echo their most nostalgic elements. What Guo Jingming likes is just like the "Tiny Times" series of the year, which is noble and decent on the surface, but frivolous on the inside.

;

;The first rule of Guo's rule: noble people must have the surname Gong. Each play has its own Tang Wanru.

;

;在《小时代》中，总裁宫洺，拥有严重洁癖，疯狂收集昂贵杯子;，看到鱼就脸色苍白，每日摄入蛋白粉以保持一张从《VOGUE》杂志第五页上撕下来的脸。 ;

;

;;

;

;;《云之羽》让我们看到了宫洺的祖师爷爷们：宫子羽，六月吃冰都会被冷到哭，体寒不失为一种娇柔的富贵病；宫尚角，不吃鸡和鱼，因为不想看到死鱼眼和死鸡眼，这一定是宫洺的DNA来源。 ;

;

;;《小时代》里热爱插科打诨、见到帅哥挪不动腿的唐宛如人设，也被挪到了《云之羽》中的宫紫商身上。正如唐宛如在时代姐妹花中的格格不入，宫紫商也是宫家的局外人，贵为千金却对帅哥侍卫死缠烂打。 ;

;

;;

;

;;郭氏法则;第二条：视觉冲击力。

;

;昔日的《小时代》在一大串令人眼花缭乱的名牌服饰和让人目眩神摇的奢华场景中让大家重新认识了上海的纸醉金迷，其中的时尚穿搭放在今天也毫不过时。甚至有很多观众认为，最适合郭敬明的职业是服装造型师和美术指导。

;

;;

;

;;到了《云之羽》，他开始热衷于对称构图和侘寂美学。喜欢的观众承认他在视觉效果上的用心，不喜欢的观众则觉得是故弄玄虚。 ;

;

;;

;

;;

;

;;

;

;;郭氏法则第;三条：撕啊，快活啊，反正有大把时光。

;

;《云之羽》中有一处互撕的名场面，可堪比《小时代》里的“顾里生日被南湘泼红酒，祝福发烂发臭”戏：继承者宫子羽被质疑德不配位，并和宫远徵扭打在一起。宫尚角走过去，丝毫不顾兄友弟恭、权力高低，给他们一人来了一巴掌。宫紫商在一旁大呼小叫，宫;子羽愤恨含泪但未还手，对面的宫尚角眉宇间写满轻蔑，而宫远徵则带着嘲讽的笑容。 ;

;

;;

;

;;不过，他比之前收敛多了，《云之羽》大部分时间是暗撕，实在忍不住了就在台面上来一;场打斗戏码，可以看出是相当克制了。

;

;郭氏法则第四条：男色消费。

;

;郭敬明总是深谙（女性）观众的心理，在屏幕上展现一款款不同类型的俊美小鲜肉。

;

;《小时代》里有顾源宫洺周崇光，;《晴雅集》里有晴明博雅鹤守月，《云之羽》中有宫家男团，“嫁入宫家，服从调剂”也一度成为热梗。 ;

;

;;

;

;;十集看下来，《云之羽》的观感徘;徊在两极之间：剧情节奏忽快忽慢，观众体验时香时臭。

;

;前四集迅速交代宫家群像与无锋刺客，切入核心剧情线较快，宫子羽父兄之死把节奏拉到顶，同时抛下了双层悬念：凶手是谁？云为衫和上官浅如何在层层危机中立足？即使前四集也充斥着女主角不合时宜的回忆、女主女二隔着楼梯慢慢讨论计划等骤缓情节点，但整体上没有;太大问题。 ;

;

;;但当宫子羽被要求通过“三域试炼”;;（作为执刃继承者必须通过的考验）;;开始，《云之羽》的节奏出现很大问题，每集一小时的时长也未交待太多有效信息。前情的铺垫让观众认为云为衫、上官浅和宫尚角都是干大事的人，但这几位厉害角色并没有推进权谋线的发展，而是日复一日进行着无意义对话。无锋和宫门的矛盾愈演愈烈，但宫门之内仍是一潭死水。 ;

;

;;更要命的是，剧情还反复出现打脸桥段。比如女刺客身上的毒半月一发作，本应按时和无锋上级接头，观众为她们试想了一百二十种短暂逃离的法子，最后的解决方式竟然是硬扛下去；又如“三域试炼”第一关被侧面烘托为险象环生的关卡，就连天赋异禀的宫尚角也花了十来天，但宫子羽竟然在云为衫的帮助下捞个箱子就过了。 ;

;

;;

;

;;《云之羽》还很擅长在每集末尾抛出悬念、次集开头消解矛盾：例如第六集末尾侍卫从云为衫的招数里看出了无锋的影子，第七集又被她三言两语搪塞过去；第九集末尾云为衫点出姨娘茗雾姬的卧底身份，第十集又说对方听错了。这些本该是重要情节的助推点，可等来的却是前进一大步后退两大步之感。 ;

;

;;

;

;;

;

;;总的来说，《云之羽》中缠绕的人物关系或许会吸;;;;引到部分观众的注意力，但张弛无度、不分轻重缓急的剧情推动会消耗大家;;的耐心。如此下去，剧集势必会高开低走。 ;

;

;;我们不是没有给过机会，只是他交出的答卷仍旧是改头换面的《小时代》。 ;

; Sun, 17 Sep 2023 19:25:02 +0800 初中两女生投毒全班：犯罪动机值得深究丨快评http://www.infzm.com/contents/256884
;;2023-09-17 18:00:00;
;

;一起触目惊心的“中学生投毒案”引发关注。 2023年9月14日，网传上海一初中发生投毒事件，多名学生饮用不明液体后出现身体不适。上海警方当天发布通报，证实确有此事。

;

;根据警情通报，9月12日事发当天15点37分浦东分局接到报警，上南中学东校有多名学生身体不适。经警方初步调查，此案系该校学生杨某某(女，13岁）与同班同学郑某某（女，13岁）所为。两人于当日上午趁体育课期间返回教室，将具有清洁漂白作用的混合液倒入同班学生的水杯内，导致多名学生出现不适症状。 “相关学生经送医治疗，均于当晚出院，现已恢复正常上课。”

;

;细审本案的全过程，有一些疑问值得辨析与追问。

;

;其一，本案仍然有待深入调查，事件全貌也需要还原之后公布。

;

;网传微信群的爆料截图显示，班里23个人都喝了“加料水”，其中十几个人洗了胃，还有几名学生肝肾功能受到了不同程度的损伤。如果这个爆料属实的话，受害学生的人数与受害程度需要后续调查的进一步确认。

;

;爆料截图还显示，投毒者中有一人是该班班长，“暑假期间就在策划报复班主任”，曾经制定了“一投毒毒杀，二汽油酒精双氧水烧死”的两套方案，涉事女生“桌肚里还有三瓶不明液体，老师去收的时候（该女生）拿起一瓶就自己想喝”，“女孩台板里面居然还有三把水果刀”。此外，两名女生平时成绩不错，还曾受过“班主任重点栽培”。

;

;网传爆料仍存在疑问，“策划报复班主任”的动机也有可究之处。试问，既然涉事女生是在针对班主任，那为何要向全班同学投毒？ “三瓶不明液体”与“三把水果刀”的情况如果属实，指向的恐怕也是更多的人，而不是单纯地报复班主任。此外“班主任栽培”的信息，与“报复班主任”的说辞，存在着难以自圆其说的矛盾之处，实难取信。

;

;从案情来看，涉事女生将动机说成“报复班主任”似乎有些牵强。但网传爆料毕竟带来了信息增量，为本案增添不少细节，不少后续解读都是依据这些细节。面对网络上的众说纷纭，警方理应深入调查这些细节，补足警情通报尚未提供的信息拼图，并及时向社会公布。

;

;其二，涉事女生的犯罪动机与犯罪性质，以及真正的犯罪成因。

;

;目前看，如果涉事女生确实成绩不错，又与老师没有明显矛盾的话，那么其作案动机确实是一个仍待解决的疑问。部分网友将本案中女生蓄谋已久的投毒行为认为是“心理精神问题”，这不符合刑法中危害行为与危害结果之间因果关系认定的基本原则。

;

;在本案中，涉事女生事先制定了犯罪计划，主动实施了犯罪行为，意在伤害全班数十名同学，存在蓄意谋杀或是“报复社会”的重大嫌疑，任何“隐情”“成因”都不能成为两名女生投毒的理由。

;

;两名女生的行为既不是出于过失，背后也不存在什么“不能抗拒或者不能预见的原因”，而是明知投毒行为会发生伤害他人、危害社会的结果，甚至存在故意杀人未遂的重大嫌疑，这是无法以任何理由予以开脱或是缓颊的。

;

;退一步讲，即便涉事女生杨某某存在“心理问题”，难道其同案犯郑某某也有“心理问题”？即便涉事女生真的是心存报复，难道全班学生都得罪了她们？显然，涉事两女生的犯罪动机值得深究，警方应严查其社交媒体以及社会关系，找到可能的教唆犯罪人，或是涉事女生受到特定极端思想影响的痕迹，追查这些真正靠谱的犯罪成因。

;

;其三，本案的善后包括惩治涉事者与救济受害者，但这两个方面仍有可议之处。

;

;据《荔枝新闻》报道，网传涉事女生家长已在班级群道歉，表示“为了失职没有驾驭好自家孩子而愧疚”。依据现行法律，两名涉事学生不满14周岁，不需承担刑事责任和行政责任，只可责令学生家长严加管教。受害学生如有医疗费等支出，家长可起诉两名学生的家长。

;

;本案中的两名女生已经构成了投放危险物质罪，而且是已遂。刑法第114条规定，放火、决水、爆炸以及投放毒害性、放射性、传染病病原体等物质或者以其他危险方法危害公共安全，尚未造成严重后果的，处三年以上十年以下有期徒刑。如果“致人重伤、死亡或者使公私财产遭受重大损失”的话，处十年以上有期徒刑、无期徒刑或者死刑。

;

;不难想见，如果本案是一个成年人蓄意向未成年人投毒的话，那么涉事者必将面临法律的严厉制裁，接受三年以上十年以下有期徒刑的刑罚。但刑法第17条规定，“已满十四周岁不满十八周岁的人犯罪，应当从轻或者减轻处罚。”本案中两名涉事女生都未满十四岁，这就给惩处她们带来了难题。

;

;从本案的情况来看，涉事女生的犯罪行为恐怕并非一时兴起，甚至不排除“卡bug”情况。如果这种情况属实的话，本案就是未成年罪犯以成人般的心智实施犯罪，却大胆凭借未成年人的身份而免于处罚了。难道对不足十四岁的未成年罪犯，社会只能任其逍遥法外吗？

;

;现行未成年人保护法似乎只能威慑与惩戒那些伤害未成年人的成年人，而对于“未成年人伤害未成年人”的情况却无能为力；同时根据义务教育法第27条的规定，学校也只能对本案中已涉嫌谋杀的涉事学生“予以批评教育，不得开除”，这显然是严重不符比例原则的。

;

;因此，根据《中华人民共和国预防未成年人犯罪法》，仅仅“批评教育”或是“严加管教”本案中的涉事女生显然是不够的，不足以惩戒犯罪行为，也无法慰藉受害同学。因此，有必要予以执行本法第41条或第45条中的“矫治教育措施”，或以“恶意补足犯罪年龄”，令其受到应有的惩罚，还受害者一个公道。

;

; Sun, 17 Sep 2023 18:25:02 +0800 国庆出行没抢到票？这些方式可提高购票成功率http://www.infzm.com/contents/256890

;

;记者从中国国家铁路集团有限公司（下称“国铁集团”）获悉，自9月13日开始发售国庆黄金周运输第一天即9月27日火车票以来，至9月16日开始发售放假第二天即9月30日车票，铁路火车票售票火热。 9月13日至16日，铁路共发售火车票7405万张，其中9月15日创下单日售票量2287.7万张的历史新高。

;

;国铁集团客运部负责人介绍，从9月13日至16日火车票预售情况来看，放假前一天9月28日和假期前两天即9月29日至30日，上海至武汉、上海至西安、深圳至长沙、上海至长沙、上海至合肥、深圳至厦门、上海至郑州、北京至郑州、北京至武汉、广州至贵阳等方向车票紧俏，部分时刻点较好、速度快的热门车次更为紧张，但北京至上海、上海至南京、上海至北京、成都至重庆、苏州至上海、杭州至上海、武汉至上海、广州至南宁、石家庄至北京、西安至北京等方向的部分车次仍有余票，其中沈阳至北京、香港至广州、深圳至香港、南宁至广州、青岛至北京、太原至北京、武汉至深圳、无锡至上海、昆明至成都等方向车次余票充足。 9月27日及其以前预售期内的车票，各个方向余票充足。

;

;该负责人介绍，假期旅客出行高度集中，部分热门方向、热点时段列车会存在车票紧张状况，旅客朋友可以根据不同时段、不同方向余票情况，选择错峰出行，也可选择候补购票、中转换乘等方式购票。

;
